snippet: A string of drug-related deaths at big music festivals has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.
abstract: String of drug-related deaths at big music festivals is highlighting risks not only to fans, but also to businesses looking to profit from electronic dance music craze; electronic dance music business has grown to estimated worth of $4.5 billion, luring Wall Street investors and corporate sponsors; several young people attending dance events around the country have died after exhibiting symptoms of overdoses from MDMA and other so-called party drugs, threatening to scare off investors and sponsors.

byline.original: By BEN SISARIO and JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr

lead_paragraph: A string of drug-related deaths at big music festivals has highlighted the risks not only to fans, but to the businesses looking to profit from the craze.

headline.main: Drug Deaths Threaten Rising Business of Electronic Music Fests
headline.print_headline: Drug Deaths Threaten Rising Business of Electronic Music Fests
